An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called simple if there exists an element $\alpha \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha)$. The degree $[K(\alpha): K]$ is referred to as the degree of $\alpha$ over $K$.
Does the concept of a/an Trivial Algebraic field extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Simple Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Simple Field Extension involves a field extension $K \subset L$ where $L$ can be generated by a single element $\(\alpha \in L\)$ over $K$. This definition focuses on the ability to express $L$ as $K(\alpha)$, where $\alpha$ is some element of $L$. The definition does not require that all elements of $L$ be algebraic over $K$, only that $L$ can be generated by a single element from $K$. 

On the other hand, the concept of a Trivial Algebraic Field Extension involves a field extension $L / K$ where every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$. This definition is concerned with the nature of the elements of $L$ in relation to $K$, specifically that they must all be algebraic over $K$. 

The definition of a Simple Field Extension does not inherently require or imply that every element of $L$ must be algebraic over $K$. It only requires that there exists at least one element $\alpha$ in $L$ such that $L$ can be generated by $\alpha$ over $K$. Therefore, the concept of a Trivial Algebraic Field Extension is not necessary for the definition of a Simple Field Extension to make sense.
